p: Permissions required to access logs are often different than permissions required to access sensitive or private user data.  Logging such data can results in unintended information disclosure.

Exception details can include operating system and .NET Framework version numbers, method names, computer names, SQL command statements, connection strings, and other details that are very useful to attackers
Follow this guideline when designing a logging architecture and when handling exceptions.
Use the following steps to avoid revealing sensitive information:
Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
ol: In the design phase, create a list of all sensitive user data your system handles.  Include composite data elements which are sensitive in combination, like multi-part registration credentials or fields which together uniquely identify an individual.  Remember that sensitive data can come in a wide variety of formats.  Names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card or other financial information, passwords, and private keys are all examples of sensitive information.  Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information.  Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data.  In general sensitive data can be defined as follows: Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with users. Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application. Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users. Ensure sensitive data does not get logged. When designing a logging architecture for your application, pay special attention to components that will handle sensitive data.  Design logging systems for these components so that they do not collect sensitive data.  When recording transactions inside your system, log only the minimum amount of information needed.  If you're logging a new order from a customer, log only the time, customer ID, and order ID.  Information like customer names, items ordered, or payment information can be reconstructed from transaction records and can be left out of the logging system. Make sure that exception details are not allowed to propagate beyond the application boundary to the client. The rich exception details included in Exception objects are valuable to developers and attackers alike. Log details by writing them in the event log to aid problem diagnosis but return generic error messages to the user.

Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with users. Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application. Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users.

Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application. Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users.
Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with users.
Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application.
Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users.

Ensure sensitive data does not get logged. When designing a logging architecture for your application, pay special attention to components that will handle sensitive data.  Design logging systems for these components so that they do not collect sensitive data.  When recording transactions inside your system, log only the minimum amount of information needed.  If you're logging a new order from a customer, log only the time, customer ID, and order ID.  Information like customer names, items ordered, or payment information can be reconstructed from transaction records and can be left out of the logging system.

Make sure that exception details are not allowed to propagate beyond the application boundary to the client. The rich exception details included in Exception objects are valuable to developers and attackers alike.
Log details by writing them in the event log to aid problem diagnosis but return generic error messages to the user.

html:
What to Do

Avoid logging sensitive or private data such as user passwords. Do not reveal too much information to the caller.

Why

Permissions required to access logs are often different than permissions required to access sensitive or private user data.  Logging such data can results in unintended information disclosure.

Exception details can include operating system and .NET Framework version numbers, method names, computer names, SQL command statements, connection strings, and other details that are very useful to attackers

When

Follow this guideline when designing a logging architecture and when handling exceptions.

How

Use the following steps to avoid revealing sensitive information:

  1. In the design phase, create a list of all sensitive user data your system handles.  Include composite data elements which are sensitive in combination, like multi-part registration credentials or fields which together uniquely identify an individual.  Remember that sensitive data can come in a wide variety of formats.  Names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card or other financial information, passwords, and private keys are all examples of sensitive information.  Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information.  Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data.  In general sensitive data can be defined as follows:
    1. Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with users.
    2. Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application.
    3. Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users.
  2. Ensure sensitive data does not get logged. When designing a logging architecture for your application, pay special attention to components that will handle sensitive data.  Design logging systems for these components so that they do not collect sensitive data.  When recording transactions inside your system, log only the minimum amount of information needed.  If you're logging a new order from a customer, log only the time, customer ID, and order ID.  Information like customer names, items ordered, or payment information can be reconstructed from transaction records and can be left out of the logging system.
  3. Make sure that exception details are not allowed to propagate beyond the application boundary to the client. The rich exception details included in Exception objects are valuable to developers and attackers alike.
  4. Log details by writing them in the event log to aid problem diagnosis but return generic error messages to the user.

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
